text:
ERIN KAIVAN: As far back as
our collective memory can go,

someone in my family has
served in the military.

My father served for 36
years in the Air Force.

I just remember his
commitment that he had,

mentoring and training,
and that really

inspired me to
pursue the same path.

I was a military
intelligence officer,

and it was the best
job I ever had.
I was a company commander.
I got to lead 120 soldiers.

I got to grow as a leader
and become confident
in myself and my own abilities.

More than anything, I
became more of myself--

but in the military, it would
have taken me 20, 30 years

to achieve the type of influence
that I think that I could have
a lot sooner through business.

I remember telling my fifth
grade teacher I was going to be

six feet tall-- which
I'm close, 5'11--

and then that I was
going to go to Harvard.

Coming from a nontraditional
background, I knew this much--
zero--
about finance, about accounting.

Did not know what a
financial model was.

In the army there
are so many programs

that everyone tells you,
don't self-select out of,

and the HBS experience and
the application process
is no different.

Through my application process
and my time at Harvard Business

School, I've learned that
the school values so much

more than being able to
fill out an Excel document.

They value leadership
and experiences,

and the whole person that
you bring to the case method.

There's so much more that
you bring that is invaluable.

Right before the
first day of school,

I remember being 5 and
1/2 months pregnant,

and I was so worried
that I was going

to be this giant pregnant
lady, and nobody was
going to want to be my friend.

And I was blown away
by everyone's warmth
and generosity.

They threw me the biggest
and most special baby shower,

I think, that anyone has
ever had, celebrating me,
my husband, my family.

We as a community
support not only

each other and our own
goals, but also the families
that everyone is going to have.

Obviously, nothing
will ever compare

to the camaraderie
or connectedness

that you have with people
that you went to combat with,

or that you served
with for years on end.

However, what I found
within the HBS community

is a huge veteran's
presence-- you have events

throughout the year
to share stories.

But I think some of the my
favorite events that we did

was celebrating Veterans'
Day, and I was blown away

by the amount of
support that came from,

not only the people
in my section,
but from the school as a whole.

I think overarching,
what I'm most

excited about post MBA is just
the unlimited possibilities
that exist.

Working the startup space
and entrepreneurship
is really interesting to me.

Doing consulting is
really interesting to me.

So there's just so many things
that I'm looking forward

to exploring in life, and
figuring out what that is

and bringing my
family along with me

as I pursue that, I'm
really looking forward to.
